sp.speaker: P
sp.p: — What , tired already !

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: — No , no , but I must go at once ! instantly !

div.stage: She rushes out , leaving a slipper behind her .

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: — What ! she has gone ! and in such haste , that she has left one of her dainty slippers behind her . I must fly to restore it to her . Princess ! Adored one ! come back !Rushes out .

div.stage: CURTAIN .

div.head: SCENE IV .

stage.stage: Room in the cottage , same as in SCENES I. and II .

sp.speaker: MAB
sp.p: —Yawning .Oh dear , I am so tired !

sp.speaker: L
sp.p: — I do wish you would leave off saying that . That is the ninth time you have yawned during the last five minutes .

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: — My dears , going to a ball does n't seem to have improved your temper .

sp.speaker: MAB
sp.p: — I do n't quite see why it should .

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: — I suppose it was dancing so much that tired you ?

sp.speaker: L
sp.p: — Of course it was — we had to dance the whole time , from the moment we entered the room .

sp.speaker: MAB
sp.p: — There were many people we were obliged to refuse , and they were heart-broken .

sp.speaker: L
sp.p: — But , of course , when the prince asked us , we were obliged to throw over the others .

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: —Smiling aside .And the prince danced with you a great deal , then ?

sp.speaker: L
sp.p: — Indeed , he did , nearly all the time , till a strange princess came , then he was obliged to leave us .

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: — A strange princess ! What was she like ?

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: — Now I think of it , she was something like you — was she not , girls ?

sp.speaker: MAB
sp.p: —Laughing .Ha ! ha ! so she was !

sp.speaker: L
sp.p: — Only she was beautiful , and you are very ugly .

sp.speaker: MAB
sp.p: — And she had beautiful silver clothes .

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: — I should like to wear silver clothes .

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: — Peggy , do not let me hear you say such foolish things again . It 's all very well for your step-sisters to wear such clothes , but for you ! !

div.stage: A sound of a trumpet heard .

sp.speaker: MAB
sp.p: — Why , what can that be ?

div.stage: Mother and daughters rush to back to look out of window .

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: —Aside .Oh , if it were the prince !

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: — It is a magnificent herald — the herald we saw last night ! He is reading a proclamation to the people , and the prince is behind him !

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: — The Prince ! !Waves to PRINCE , unseen by the others .

div.stage: The HERALD stops outside the window .

sp.speaker: H
sp.p: —In a loud voice .“ Be it known to all the loyal subjects of Prince Charming , our lord and master , that yesterday evening , at the ball , an embroidered silver slipper was picked up . The prince has commanded that the said slipper shall be carried through the length and breadth of his dominions , until he finds the owner of it . When the owner of it is discovered , that said owner shall become the Princess Charming , and shall share our lord and master 's throne . ”

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: — My dear girls , what a chance for you ! If you can put on the shoe , you will become the princess .

sp.speaker: MAB
sp.p: — The herald is stopping before this door . Quick ! quick ! Let us sit in pretty attitudes .

div.stage: LUCY and MABEL group themselves picturesquely .

sp.speaker: L
sp.p: — But Peggy must not be here , Mother ! Go away , Peggy , quick !

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: — Rush , child , rush ! Do n't let any one see you .

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: — May I not stay to see the silver shoe ?

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: — You ! Of course not ! Why the very look of you would spoil all our chances .Pushing her .Quick ! quick ! they are just coming in .

div.stage: Bundles PEGGY out of door L. just as the HERALD comes in R. He blows trumpet .

sp.speaker: H
sp.p: — His Royal Highness , Prince Charming .

div.stage: Enter PRINCE . MOTHER , LUCY , and MABEL curtsey .

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: — Oh , your highness , this is too kind , pray sit down .

div.stage: She advances a chair . The other two curtsey , one on each side of him .

sp.speaker: H
sp.p: — We wish to know if any lady in this house lost a shoe at the ball last night ? For , if so , her shoe has been found .

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: —Eagerly .What a singular thing ! Now you mention it , one of my daughters lost a shoe — indeed , they both did .

sp.speaker: H
sp.p: — Indeed ! Is it anything like this ?Produces shoe .

sp.speaker: L
sp.p: — Why , that looks to me like the very one .

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: — Try it on , please , madam .

sp.speaker: L
sp.p: —Holding out her foot , making faces while the HERALD puts it on .Why , of course , that is mine , it fits me exactly .

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: — It fits the darling girl as if it had been made for her . Walk round the room in it , my love .

div.stage: LUCY hobbles round the room , limping violently .

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: — Oh , there is no doubt , your highness , that that is hers .

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: — Did n't I notice a slight limp as she walked ?

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: — Oh dear no , your highness , I do n't think so .

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: — All the same , I think she had better take it off .

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: — And you , Mabel , did n't you say you had lost one of your shoes ?

sp.speaker: MAB
sp.p: — Yes ! I remember when I undressed noticing that I had lost it .

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: — Then , of course , it must be yours .

div.stage: The HERALD kneels beside her , tries to force on the shoe , while MABEL makes faces of agony .

sp.speaker: MAB
sp.p: — Oh , not a doubt , that is mine .Stands up .

sp.speaker: H
sp.p: — Your heel is quite out of it still .

sp.speaker: MAB
sp.p: — That is how I always wear my shoes .

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: — That is what gives her such a springy , graceful walk .

div.stage: MABEL tries to walk round the room , clattering the shoe behind her .

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: — No , I am afraid that wo n't do at all .

sp.speaker: MAB
sp.p: —Shaking it off .It 's very hard not being allowed to have my own shoe back again .

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: —To the MOTHER .Are there no more young girls in this house , whom the shoe would be likely to fit ?

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: — Alas , these two fair ones are my only joys .

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: — Yet , I thought , as I passed the window , I saw another .

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: — Oh , your highness , I beg your pardon — that was only our scullion , looking out to see you . Naughty thing !

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: — I wish to see her .

sp.speaker: L
sp.p: — Oh , really , your highness !

sp.speaker: MAB
sp.p: — She is a most unprepossessing girl !

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: — Send for her instantly , or I will have you all beheaded .

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: —Quickly .Anything , anything , to oblige your highness .

div.stage: Calls PEGGY .
CINDERELLA appears in the doorway , with her eyes cast down . PRINCE jumps up and bows very low . LUCY , MABEL , and MOTHER , turn away their eyes in disgust .

sp.speaker: H
sp.p: — Sit down here , fair maiden , and try on this silver shoe .

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: — Nay , no one shall kneel here but me .Kneels in front of CINDERELLA , who puts on the shoe without difficulty .There , I think , is the foot it fits , there is no doubt about that .

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: — I fear your highness is being imposed upon — that shoe could never have belonged to that ragged Cinderella .

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: — Indeed it did — I have the fellow to it .

div.stage: Pulls the other out of her pocket . Gets up and dances round in it .

lg.l: — There is no doubt to whom the slipper belongs . Come , Princess
Charming , let me lead you to your palace !

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: — One moment , if you please , your royal highness ! the girl is a scullion !

sp.speaker: L
sp.p: — You have only to look at her clothes !

sp.speaker: MAB
sp.p: — Mine would be far fitter to adorn a throne !

div.stage: Enter FAIRY GODMOTHER .

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: — The clothes are my business — I will see that Princess Charming is not dressed like a scullion .

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: — My fairy godmother !

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: — Her fairy godmother !

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: — The same . So , Cinderella , if you will step into that dark cupboard while I recite a magic spell , you shall be changed into a beautiful princess .

div.stage: CINDERELLA enters the cupboard . The FAIRY GODMOTHER recites spell , waves wand . CINDERELLA comes out dressed as she was at the ball . Mother and daughters start .

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: — Now , my child , no one can say you look like a scullion .

sp.speaker: L
sp.p: and M .— The Princess of the Silver Mountain !

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: — The same , whom you left sitting in the ashes , but who went to the ball after all —

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: — And was the most beautiful princess there .

div.stage: Bows and kisses her hand .

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: — I wish , my darlings , I had chosen a fairy for your godmother , instead of those silly aunts of yours .

sp.speaker: L
sp.p: — I must say , it is very hard on us that a chit like that should have the best of everything .

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: — Come , if you say one word more , I will repeat my spell backwards over you , and then all your clothes will change to rags .

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: — Come , then , my pretty poppets , come away with me , you are not appreciated here as you deserve .

sp.speaker: L
sp.p: — No , we are not admired as we ought to be .

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: — Pray , madam , do not let us turn you out , as we are going ourselves . Come , my princess .

div.stage: Offers his hand .

sp.speaker: H
sp.p: —Loudly .Bring forward the princess 's golden coach !

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: —Waving wand .Be happy , my Cinderella ! CURTAIN . THE ABERDEEN UNIVERSITY PRESS LIMITED . By the same Author .
